reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central framing assumption of the essay: that “mostly-great futures are a narrow target,” which is used throughout to motivate pessimism about convergence and to make trade/threats decisive. However, it attacks this via one sub-argument in §4.1 (alien/inaccessible best experiences), so it doesn’t engage the essay’s broader bases for narrowness (e.g., fussy axiologies, many free parameters, divergence under antirealism, threat dynamics). The key inference—‘if we can’t conceptualize the best experiences, we can’t assess whether the target is narrow’—is only partially correct: one can coherently think the optimum is alien while also thinking the set of futures capturing most value is small, based on structural/optimization arguments rather than direct conceptual access. Also, the “alien experience” point is used mainly to block a specific optimistic route (self-interest leading to near-best), not to sustain the essay’s broader pessimism about moral convergence; so the “opportunistic” charge somewhat overstates the inconsistency. Still, it correctly highlights a tension about epistemic access and rhetorical asymmetry (using unknowability to dismiss optimism but not to weaken pessimistic priors). The critique is clear, focused, and contains little fluff, but overall poses only a modest problem for the position.
title: Alien experience arguments are applied asymmetrically to defeat optimism while preserving pessimism
